segment.source: Identify Users (Windows 10)
segment.target: Identify Users (Windows 10)

segment.source: Identify Users
segment.target: Identify Users

segment.source: Identify Users
segment.target: Identify Users

segment.source: It is important to carefully consider how you plan to migrate users.
segment.target: It is important to carefully consider how you plan to migrate users.

segment.source: By default, all users are migrated by User State Migration Tool (USMT) 5.0.
segment.target: By default, all users are migrated by User State Migration Tool (USMT) 5.0.

segment.source: You must specify which users to include by using the command line.
segment.target: You must specify which users to include by using the command line.

segment.source: You cannot specify users in the .xml files.
segment.target: You cannot specify users in the .xml files.

segment.source: For instructions on how to migrate users, see Migrate User Accounts.
segment.target: For instructions on how to migrate users, see Migrate User Accounts.

segment.source: In This Topic
segment.target: In This Topic

segment.source: Migrating Local Accounts
segment.target: Migrating Local Accounts

segment.source: Migrating Domain Accounts
segment.target: Migrating Domain Accounts

segment.source: Command-Line Options
segment.target: Command-Line Options

segment.source: Migrating Local Accounts
segment.target: Migrating Local Accounts

segment.source: Before migrating local accounts, note the following:
segment.target: Before migrating local accounts, note the following:

segment.source: You must explicitly specify that local accounts that are not on the destination computer should be migrated.
segment.target: You must explicitly specify that local accounts that are not on the destination computer should be migrated.

segment.source: If you are migrating local accounts and the local account does not exist on the destination computer, you must use the/lac option when using the LoadState command.
segment.target: If you are migrating local accounts and the local account does not exist on the destination computer, you must use the/lac option when using the LoadState command.

segment.source: If the /lac option is not specified, no local user accounts will be migrated.
segment.target: If the /lac option is not specified, no local user accounts will be migrated.

segment.source: Consider whether to enable user accounts that are new to the destination computer.
segment.target: Consider whether to enable user accounts that are new to the destination computer.

segment.source: The /lae option enables the account that was created with the /lac option.
segment.target: The /lae option enables the account that was created with the /lac option.

segment.source: However, if you create a disabled local account by using only the /lac option, a local administrator must enable the account on the destination computer.
segment.target: However, if you create a disabled local account by using only the /lac option, a local administrator must enable the account on the destination computer.

segment.source: Be careful when specifying a password for local accounts.
segment.target: Be careful when specifying a password for local accounts.

segment.source: If you create the local account with a blank password, anyone could log on to that account on the destination computer.
segment.target: If you create the local account with a blank password, anyone could log on to that account on the destination computer.

segment.source: If you create the local account with a password, the password is available to anyone with access to the USMT command-line tools.
segment.target: If you create the local account with a password, the password is available to anyone with access to the USMT command-line tools.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If there are multiple users on a computer, and you specify a password with the /lac option, all migrated users will have the same password.
segment.target: If there are multiple users on a computer, and you specify a password with the /lac option, all migrated users will have the same password.

segment.source: Migrating Domain Accounts
segment.target: Migrating Domain Accounts

segment.source: The source and destination computers do not need to be connected to the domain for domain user profiles to be migrated.
segment.target: The source and destination computers do not need to be connected to the domain for domain user profiles to be migrated.

segment.source: Command-Line Options
segment.target: Command-Line Options

segment.source: USMT provides several options to migrate multiple users on a single computer.
segment.target: USMT provides several options to migrate multiple users on a single computer.

segment.source: The following command-line options specify which users to migrate.
segment.target: The following command-line options specify which users to migrate.

segment.source: Specifying users.
segment.target: Specifying users.

segment.source: You can specify which users to migrate with the /all, /ui, /uel, and /ue options with both the ScanState and LoadState command-line tools.
segment.target: You can specify which users to migrate with the /all, /ui, /uel, and /ue options with both the ScanState and LoadState command-line tools.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: The /uel option excludes users based on the LastModified date of the Ntuser.dat file.
segment.target: The /uel option excludes users based on the LastModified date of the Ntuser.dat file.

segment.source: The /uel option is not valid in offline migrations.
segment.target: The /uel option is not valid in offline migrations.

segment.source: Moving users to another domain.
segment.target: Moving users to another domain.

segment.source: You can move user accounts to another domain using the /md option with the LoadState command-line tool.
segment.target: You can move user accounts to another domain using the /md option with the LoadState command-line tool.

segment.source: Creating local accounts.
segment.target: Creating local accounts.

segment.source: You can create and enable local accounts using the /lac and /lae options with the LoadState command-line tool.
segment.target: You can create and enable local accounts using the /lac and /lae options with the LoadState command-line tool.

segment.source: Renaming user accounts.
segment.target: Renaming user accounts.

segment.source: You can rename user accounts using the /mu option.
segment.target: You can rename user accounts using the /mu option.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: By default, if a user name is not specified in any of the command-line options, the user will be migrated.
segment.target: By default, if a user name is not specified in any of the command-line options, the user will be migrated.
